snippet: Revelations about the N.S.A. surveillance efforts in Europe are resulting in unprecedented backlash, and some wonder if it is more important to collect data on allies or to be able to work with them.
abstract: News analysis; Rene Obermann, chief executive of German telecommunications giant Deutsche Telekom, tells a cybersecurity conference in Germany that his company is working to keep electronic message traffic from 'unnecessarily' crossing the Atlantic, where it could fall into the hands of the National Security Agency; admission is part of an unprecedented backlash in Europe to revelations about NSA surveillance efforts.

byline.original: By ALISON SMALE and DAVID E. SANGER
byline.contributor: Alison Smale reported from Berlin, and David E. Sanger from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Revelations about the N.S.A. surveillance efforts in Europe are resulting in unprecedented backlash, and some wonder if it is more important to collect data on allies or to be able to work with them.

headline.main: Spying Scandal Alters U.S. Ties With Allies and Raises Talk of Policy Shift
headline.print_headline: Spying Scandal Alters Ties With Allies and Leads to Talk of U.S. Policy Shift
